Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Atmospheric Remote Sensing Focused Around the CSU-CHILL National Radar Facility
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a REU Site at the Colorado State University CSU-CHILL polarized Doppler radar facility, which serves as a focal point for advanced research and education in radar engineering and radar meteorology. The emphasis on remote sensing and radar meteorology, and collaboration with engineering, enables students to gain experience with technology development as well as scientific research.

The site provides summer research experiences at the CHILL facility for six students, usually following their junior year. The students spend 10 weeks in residence at CSU. The program encompasses a full research experience, from literature survey, developing background on instrumentation, developing research topics, and through to the actual research. At the end of the project, students will write a formal report and present their results in research seminars. Opportunities will also be available through the National Center for Atmospheric Research, NCAR. In addition, the facility has completed a major initiative to create a virtual radar facility over the Internet. Through this, extensive support will be provided for radar experiments, data, and computer links, so that students may continue their work at their home institutions as part of their senior projects if desired.

The CSU-CHILL REU Site enables a new generation of researchers to gain familiarity with scientists at a major research center and hands-on experience with cutting-edge interdisciplinary research using a highly advanced weather radar system. The power and flexibility of this system makes it convenient for undergraduate students to learn radar operations, data collection, product display, and generation of new products.

The intellectual merit of this effort centers on unique student-driven activities bridging the atmospheric science and engineering communities. Broader impacts are wide ranging, and include involvement of student participants drawn from underrepresented groups and facilitation of exchange among representatives of multiple scientific disciplines. Participation by faculty, CSU-CHILL staff, and NCAR staff will enable the students to acquire a strong theoretical and experimental background while participating in a mix of team-oriented and individual research projects making use of this unique radar facility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CSU-CHILL REU program over its lifetime has served to introduce a large number of undergraduate students in multiple disciplines to research in engineering, atmospheric science, and remote sensing . CSU-CHILL radar is a unique national research radar facility. Students in the CSU-CHILL REU are given the opportunity to work with leaders in their fields, on cutting edge research topics and field campaigns.

 

The unique focus of this REU in particular is its emphasis on true multidisciplinary research. Beyond just accepting multiple disciplines, students were expected to work with partners of vastly different backgrounds on projects driven by the students themselves.  Research projects always span engineering and science and involve students from both disciplines. This early introduction to integrative collaboration gives students a leg up in a global research environment that is increasingly becoming multidisciplinary.

 

A core tenet of the CSU-CHILL REU program is that students take responsibility for their own project. Participants are not a small part of a professor’s project; rather they take initiative, and are responsible for developing a proposal as well as driving their research.  This  REU  research covered many topics through the years.

 

In recent years students have calculated radar climatology , explored how new 3D models of hailstones can improve radar detection of hail, developed advanced image processing techniques for processing hail pad images, implemented mapping capabilities into software packages, implemented advanced storm classification algorithms, programmed new semantic processing systems for remote sensing data, explored new multi-facility operational networks and demonstrated their capabilities, tracked lightning in storms, and developed a balloon system for helping to automate calibration of weather radars, among many others. This is just a small sampling of the various student projects. All of these projects have been at the forefront of research and driven by the students with support from their mentors.

 

More than just generating great research, the program has had a large focus on ensuring students succeed in their future careers. Students were supported to attend conferences in their field, and mentors have often served on students senior project committees after they return to their home institution.  During the program, a large number of field trips are scheduled to make sure students are introduced to  research activities in the nearby area. This has included time to meet with faculty at CSU. Students regularly attend top tier schools and excelled in their fields. A significant percentage of the students have gone on to attend graduate programs, in various institutions such as  MIT, Johns Hopkins, and CSU, while others have pursued careers with national laboratories and in private industry.
